awd_titl_txt: Effects on Supernovae and their Remnants of Asymmetric Envelopes Caused by Outflow from Binary-star Progenitors
awd_abstract_narration:
The violent star explosions, known as supernovae, are responsible for
many features of our Universe.  They produce and distribute many of
the heavy elements that make up stars, new planets, and also people.
The energy supernovae release into the interstellar gas heats and stirs it,
and some of that energy goes to accelerating a few subatomic particles
to extreme energies -- the enigmatic cosmic rays that fill our Galaxy
and constantly rain down on the Earth.  In the last few thousand years,
several Galactic supernovae were visible at Earth and carefully
recorded by naked-eye observers. The remnants of those supernovae,
expanding gas clouds emitting radio waves, X-rays, and visible light,
can now be studied in detail, along with hundreds of older remnants
from supernovae too distant to be seen on Earth with the naked
eye. This proposal will model the effects of supernovae that occur in 
systems with two stars gravitationally bound to each other. 

Recent evidence suggests that many supernovae originate in binary systems, 
pairs of stars orbiting one another.  The more massive stars shed material as they 
age, particularly in the stages just prior to explosion, so the explosions 
take place in a complicated environment of gas.  These investigators will compute
state-of-the-art simulations of pre-supernova environments, and then model
the explosion, to see what effects it has on the appearance of the supernovae 
at the time of the event, and on the remnants of the events, which are still
thousands of years later.  

The investigators hope to identify particular features that such supernovae
and remnants might show that would be clues to the environments that
gave rise to them.  In addition, a few particular objects, such as
historical remnants from supernovae seen at Earth in the last few
hundred years, will be studied, to try to identify the types of stars that 
created the explosions.

The investigators will use high-performance computing systems at national 
facilities, and will train students in the most up-to-date applications of 
computing to complex problems.  Improving our understanding of supernovae adds an
essential piece to the grand narrative of the nature of our Universe
and the place of humanity in it.

por.por_cntn:
The violent stellar explosions known as supernovae are responsible for many features of our Universe.  They produce and distribute heavy elements that make up new stars, planets, and astronomers.  The energy they release into the interstellar gas heats and stirs it, and some of that energy goes to accelerating a few subatomic particles to extreme energies -- the enigmatic cosmic rays that fill our Galaxy and constantly rain down on the Earth.  In the last few millennia, several Galactic supernovae were visible to the naked eye at Earth and carefully recorded, and the remnants of those supernovae, expanding gas clouds emitting radio waves, X-rays, and visible light, can now be studied in detail, along with hundreds of older remnants from supernovae too distant to have been seen on Earth with the naked eye.  A great deal is unknown about the stars or star systems that give rise to supernovae.  Recent evidence suggests that many supernovae originate in binary systems of two stars orbiting one another. Massive stars shed material as they age, particularly in the stages just prior to explosion, so the explosions take place in a complicated environment of gas.  This project proposed to use state-of-the-art
computing to simulate that presupernova environment, and then to explode simulated supernovae in it, to see what effects it has on the appearance of the supernovae themselves, or hundreds to thousands of years later, on the remnants of those supernovae.  Comparison of our simulations with observed events can lead to better understanding of the nature of the stellar explosions.

Our calculations required sophisticated numerical techniques and supercomputer resources to simulate the surprisingly complex gas flows in the vicinity of the two stars.  The bulk of the work was done by graduate student C. Kolb, who is now proficient in several areas of high-performance computing.  We calculated 3D gas distributions for a range of binary systems, and characterized their average properties to make them readily usable by other researchers.  Further away from the stars than several times their separation, the flows are well described as disks, with the pole-to-equator density ratio and the angle containing half the mass as simple classifiers.

These simulation results represent the first of our two goals for this project.  Calculating their consequences for the appearance of the supernova and its eventual remnant is our second goal.  We created a modeling code that can use these simulation results as input to calculate the "light echos" from the initial burst of supernova light, as it passes through the disk, destroying dust grains near the stars and heating dust at larger distances, producing a variable infrared signal which can last for months.  The predictions can be compared
with observations.  We also developed a calculational framework to predict the radio signal from the supernova shock wave traversing the disk.  Preliminary results have been obtained.  Predictions for the much later appearance of the supernova remnant should be forthcoming soon.

We expect our work to have impact beyond the community of researchers
performing similar calculations.  We expect that the framework we have developed to calculate the distribution of stellar-wind material in binary star systems, and its effect on the eventual supernova explosion of one of the stars, will be applicable to many observed events, and will be an important tool for the observational community to use in interpreting future supernova detections.  Our calculated distributions of circumstellar material will be made available to other researchers as input to other types of theoretical calculation,
as well.  In the course of the project, our graduate student has sharpened his already formidable programming skills and added deeper understanding of the power and pitfalls of high-performance computing. His images and animations have won awards, and have brought the work of this project before audiences of non-scientists.  Additional simulations were performed by an undergraduate student; she is now pursuing an advanced degree in physics.  We are proud of our contribution to the development of a sophisticated national scientific workforce.  In general, we hope to have contributed to the growing understanding of supernovae, whose effects have shaped the nature of the Universe we live in.



Last Modified: 10/15/2020
Modified by: Stephen P Reynolds

Images (1 of )
  • A red supergiant star (RSG), destined to explode, emits a wind while orbiting a secondary star. The combination of rotation and the secondary's gravity sweeps the wind into a spiral. Turbulence (blue) and an outward-moving shock wave (green) are shown.
    C. Kolb
    Stephen P Reynolds
    Stellar wind from a star in a binary system
  • A top-down view of the signature spiral shockwave.
    C. Kolb
    Creative Commons
    Stephen P Reynolds
    Binary stellar-wind spiral (top view)
  • A simulated supernova remnant shaped by the environment its progenitor created. Far from the exploded star, the wind spiral has become a dense disk in the orbital plane. The blastwave (brown) is not able to travel as fast in the disk plane as toward the poles, producing an elongated remnant.
    C. Kolb
    Creative Commons
    Stephen P Reynolds
    Supernova in a dense disk
  • Simulated radio emission from the aspherical supernova remnant. The dense disk of gas in the supernova's equatorial plane is tilted from our perspective. Radio emission from half of the remnant is not able to penetrate it and is not visible.
    C. Kolb
    Creative Commons
    Stephen P Reynolds
    Radio image of asymmetrical supernova remnant
